Define Documentation

#define ABS ( x   )     ((x) < 0 ? -(x) : (x))

Macro returning the absolute value of x.

Assumes the following operations make sense:

  • Negation: -(x)
  • less-than comparison with the integer zero: (x) < 0

Unfortunately, the only way in C to avoid evaluating x in this macro more than once is to rely on gcc-specific typing tricks. There's no way (as far as I know) to get away with it in ANSI C99. If we were coding in Common Lisp it would be easy ;)

#define ASSIGN ( voidp1,
voidp2   ) 

Value:

do { \
  if (A->value_type == REAL)        \
    memcpy ((voidp1), (voidp2), block_size * sizeof(double)); \
  else if (A->value_type == COMPLEX) \
    memcpy ((voidp1), (voidp2), block_size * sizeof(double_Complex)); \
} while(0)

#define ASSIGN ( voidp1,
voidp2   ) 

Value:

do { \
  memcpy ((voidp1), (voidp2), block_size * sizeof(double)); \
} while(0)

#define ASSIGN ( voidp1,
voidp2   ) 

Value:

do { \
  memcpy ((voidp1), (voidp2), block_size * sizeof(double_Complex)); \
} while(0)

#define SWAP ( array,
i,
j   ) 

Value:

do { \
  if (A->value_type == REAL)  \
    { \
      double* __v = (double*) (array);                     \
      memcpy (swapspace, &__v[block_size * i], block_size * sizeof(double));            \
      memcpy (&__v[block_size * i], &__v[block_size * j], block_size * sizeof(double)); \
      memcpy (&__v[block_size * j], swapspace, block_size * sizeof(double));         \
    } \
  else if (A->value_type == COMPLEX) \
    { \
      double_Complex* __v = (double_Complex*) (array);     \
      memcpy (swapspace, &__v[block_size * i], block_size * sizeof(double_Complex)); \
      memcpy (&__v[block_size * i], &__v[block_size * j], block_size * sizeof(double_Complex));   \
      memcpy (&__v[block_size * j], swapspace, block_size * sizeof(double_Complex)); \
    } \
} while(0)

#define SWAP ( array,
i,
j   ) 

Value:

do { \
  double* __v = (double*) (array);                     \
  memcpy (swapspace, &__v[block_size * i], block_size * sizeof(double));            \
  memcpy (&__v[block_size * i], &__v[block_size * j], block_size * sizeof(double)); \
  memcpy (&__v[block_size * j], swapspace, block_size * sizeof(double));         \
} while(0)

#define SWAP ( array,
i,
j   ) 

Value:

do { \
  double_Complex* __v = (double_Complex*) (array);                     \
  memcpy (swapspace, &__v[block_size * i], block_size * sizeof(double_Complex));            \
  memcpy (&__v[block_size * i], &__v[block_size * j], block_size * sizeof(double_Complex)); \
  memcpy (&__v[block_size * j], swapspace, block_size * sizeof(double_Complex));         \
} while(0)

#define SWAP_INTS ( array,
i,
j   ) 

Value:

do { \
  int_swapspace = array[i]; \
  array[i] = array[j]; \
  array[j] = int_swapspace; \
} while(0)

#define VOIDAREF ( array,
idx   )     ((void*) ((char*) (array) + size*(idx)))

Works like (void*) (&array[idx]), in which array is treated as an array of objects, each of which satisfies sizeof(object) == size. "size" must be a variable or constant in scope ("deliberate variable capture").

Function Documentation

void bcoo_matrix_add_entry ( struct bcoo_matrix_t *  A,
const int  bi,
const int  bj,
const void *  value 
)

Adds an entry to the given sparse matrix structure representation.

Parameters:
A [IN/OUT] Sparse matrix data structure in block coordinate (BCOO) format
bi [IN] Block row index at which to add the block (block row index of the upper left corner of the block)
bj [IN] Block column index at which to add the block (block column index of the upper left corner of the block)
value [IN] Pointer to the value to add (type depends on A->value_type). If value_type is PATTERN, you can set value==NULL.
If ownership is currently USER_DEALLOCATES, this function changes the ownership to LIBRARY_DEALLOCATES, as increasing the length of the internal arrays may require reallocation.

void bcoo_matrix_coalesce_duplicate_entries ( struct bcoo_matrix_t *  A,
int *  num_removed 
)

Coalesces duplicate entries in the given BCOO format sparse matrix. For example, if the original matrix has two entries: (30, 45, 1.23) and (30, 45, 4.56), the resulting matrix will have one entry: (30, 45, 5.79).

Parameters:
A [IN/OUT] Sparse matrix in BCOO format
num_removed [OUT] The number of duplicate entries removed from A

void bcoo_matrix_realloc ( struct bcoo_matrix_t *  A,
const int  newmaxlength 
)

Reallocates the II, JJ and val arrays in the bcoo_matrix struct to be of length newmaxlength. Adjusts nnzb only if necessary (i.e. only if the size of the arrays is to be reduced). This is a helper function for bcoo_matrix_resize.

If ownership is currently USER_DEALLOCATES, this function changes the ownership to LIBRARY_DEALLOCATES.

See also:
bcoo_matrix_resize
Parameters:
A [IN/OUT]
newmaxlength [IN] New length of the II and JJ arrays

void bcoo_matrix_resize ( struct bcoo_matrix_t *  A,
const int  newlength 
)

Resizes the II, JJ and val arrays in the bcoo_matrix_t struct to have the new given length. Allocates more memory (thus adjusting nnzb_upper_bound) only if necessary.

If ownership is currently USER_DEALLOCATES, this function changes the ownership to LIBRARY_DEALLOCATES.

Parameters:
A [IN/OUT]
newlength [IN] New lengths of (i.e. number of entries stored in) the II, JJ and val arrays. Has nothing to do with the actual amount of allocated space for these arrays. nnzb_upper_bound space is allocated, but nnzb entries are stored.

struct bcsr_matrix_t* bcoo_matrix_to_random_bcsr_matrix ( struct bcoo_matrix_t *  A  ) 

Given a sparse matrix in block coordinate (BCOO) format, generates a block compressed sparse row (BCSR) matrix with the same structure and real-valued random entries from a uniform [-1,1] distribution. As a side effect, coalesces duplicate entries from the BCOO matrix.

Parameters:
A [IN] Sparse matrix structure in BCOO format
Returns:
BCSR sparse matrix with the same structure as the input and real-valued random entries; if error, returns NULL.

struct bcsr_matrix_t* bcoo_to_bcsr ( struct bcoo_matrix_t *  A  ) 

Given a sparse matrix in block coordinate (BCOO) format, generates a copy in BCSR (block compressed sparse row) format. As a side effect, coalesces duplicate entries from the BCOO matrix.

Parameters:
A [IN] Sparse matrix in BCOO format
Returns:
BCSR format sparse matrix, which is a copy of the input matrix

struct bcoo_matrix_t* create_bcoo_matrix ( const int  bm,
const int  bn,
const int  r,
const int  c,
const int  nnzb,
const int  nnzb_upper_bound,
int *  II,
int *  JJ,
void *  val,
enum index_base_t  index_base,
enum symmetry_type_t  symmetry_type,
enum symmetric_storage_location_t  symmetric_storage_location,
enum value_type_t  value_type,
enum ownership_mode_t  ownership,
void(*)(void *)  deallocator,
enum copy_mode_t  copy_mode 
)

Creates an initially empty bcoo_matrix object with the given characteristics.

Parameters:
bm [IN] Number of block rows
bn [IN] Number of block columns
r [IN] Number of rows in each dense subblock
c [IN] Number of columns in each dense subblock
Returns:
Dynamically allocated bcoo_matrix object

struct bcoo_matrix_t* create_empty_bcoo_matrix ( const int  bm,
const int  bn,
const int  r,
const int  c,
enum index_base_t  index_base,
enum symmetry_type_t  symmetry_type,
enum symmetric_storage_location_t  symmetric_storage_location,
enum value_type_t  value_type 
)

Ownership is of course LIBRARY_DEALLOCATES and copy_mode is NO_COPY.

void destroy_bcoo_matrix ( struct bcoo_matrix_t *  A  ) 

Destroys the storage used by the given bcoo_matrix_t, and destroys the handle as well.

Parameters:
A [IN/OUT]

int print_bcoo_matrix_in_matrix_market_format ( FILE *  out,
struct bcoo_matrix_t *  A 
)

Prints the given BCOO matrix in MatrixMarket coordinate format to the given output file.

Parameters:
out [OUT] Valid output file
A [IN] BCOO format matrix
Returns:
Zero if no error, else nonzero (nothing is printed if there is an error).

int save_bcoo_matrix_in_matrix_market_format ( const char *const   filename,
struct bcoo_matrix_t *  A 
)

Saves the given BCOO format sparse matrix to the given file in MatrixMarket format.

Parameters:
filename [IN] Name of file to which to save the matrix
A [IN] The matrix to save
Returns:
Nonzero if error, else zero.

int valid_bcoo_matrix_p ( struct bcoo_matrix_t *  A  ) 

If A is valid, returns 1, else returns 0. By "valid," we mean that all the dimension parameters are within reasonable ranges and all the indices are within their appropriate ranges.

Parameters:
A [IN] Pointer to a BCOO matrix structure object
Returns:
One if A is valid, else zero.

Variable Documentation

const int BCOO_ARRAY_INIT_LENGTH = 16

Initial length allocated for the II and JJ arrays in bcoo_matrix_t.
